item1_summary:
Our revenue, earnings, cash flows, receivables, and payables are subject to fluctuations due to changes in foreign currency exchange rates . We believe our existing cash and cash equivalents, our anticipated cash flows from operations, and our available revolving credit facility will be sufficient to meet our working capital and operating resource expenditure requirements for at least the next 12 months .
 The decrease in cash provided by working capital was primarily due to a decrease in deferred revenue of $316 million driven by the transition of multi-year subscription contracts billed upfront to annual billing installments . The following table summarizes our significant financial contractual obligations at January 31, 2025, and the effect such obligations are expected to have on our liquidity and cash flows in future periods .
 Purchasing obligations relate primarily to acquisition of cloud services, marketing and commitments related to our investment agreements with limited liability partnership funds . Operating leases consist primarily of obligations for real estate, vehicles, and certain equipment . Pension obligations relate to our obligations for pension plans outside of the United States . Purchasing and purchase obligations are contractual obligations for purchase of goods or services .
 The expected timing of payment of the obligations discussed above is estimated based on current information . Timing of payments and actual amounts paid may be different depending on the time of receipt of goods or services or changes to agreed-upon amounts for some obligations . We do not have significant agreements for the purchase of supplies or other goods specifying minimum quantities or set prices exceeding our expected requirements for three months .
 Our stock repurchase programs provide us with the ability to offset the dilution from the issuance of stock under our employee stock plans and reduce shares outstanding over time . The pace and timing of repurchases will depend on factors such as cash generation from operations, available surplus, the volume of employee stock plan activity, remaining shares available in the authorized pool .
 Our revenue, earnings, cash flows, receivables, and payables are subject to fluctuations due to changes in foreign currency exchange rates . As of January 31, 2025 and 2024, we had open cash flow and balance sheet hedge contracts with future settlements generally within one to 12 months . Contracts were primarily denominated in Euros, British pounds, Japanese yen, Canadian dollars, Singapore dollars, Australian dollars, Swiss francs, Norwegian krone, and Swedish Krona .
 A hypothetical 10% appreciation of the U.S. dollar from its value at January 31, 2025 and 2024, would increase the fair value of our foreign currency contracts by $209 million and $121 million, respectively . At January 31, 2025, we had $1.32 billion of cash equivalents and marketable securities . Privately held company investments generally are considered inherently risky .
 The basis for these evaluations is subject to the timing and accuracy of the data received from these companies . See Part II, Item 8, Note 3, “Financial Instruments” in the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for further discussion regarding these strategic investments . For information about exposure to counter-party credit-related losses, see Part II .
 The Company's net income is $1,061 per share . The company's net gain (loss) on derivative instruments (net of tax effect of $2, $6.19) and $3.78 per share is based on share per share average share per-share size . Total comprehensive income   $1.061-$857 per share.
 The company paid $10,833 $9,912 preferred stockholders' equity and $1,855 proceeded in consolidated cash flow flows from the fiscal year ended January 31, receiving financial statements of the company . The company's current liabilities include current liabilities, operating lease liabilities, accrued compensation and deferred income taxes .
 Investments, net of cash acquired, cash provided by operating activities: Purchases of marketable securities; Investing activities ; Sales of marketable securities; Maturities of marketable stock markets were purchases and investments ; . Cash flow disclosure: Cash paid for interest; cash paid for income taxes, net of tax refunds, tax refunds; Cash paid for interest received for interest; .
 See accompanying Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements . The financial statements are presented at the bottom of each page of the following page . The company provides a summary of the financial statements each of the company’s financial statements . The results of each company's operations will be determined at the end of each respective fiscal year .
 Autodesk, Inc. is a global leader in 3D design, engineering and entertainment technology solutions . The Company’s sophisticated software products, offered through a hybrid of desktop and cloud functionality, enable its customers to design, fabricate, manufacture, and build anything by visualizing, simulating, and analyzing real-world performance early in the design process .
 Autodesk changed presentation of the amortization of costs capitalized to obtain a contract with a customer in our Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows . The Company also makes assumptions, judgments, and estimates in determining the accruals for uncertain tax positions, variable compensation, partner incentive programs, loss contingencies, and operating lease liabilities .
 Autodesk is a global leader in 3D design, engineering and entertainment technology solutions . The chief operating decision maker (“CODM”) assesses performance and decides how to allocate resources based on consolidated net income as reported on the Consolidated Statements of Operations . The measure of the Company’s segment assets is reported as total assets . The CODM reviews financial information presented on a consolidated basis for purposes of allocating resources, evaluating financial performance .
 The CODM also uses the budget to actual comparisons of total net revenue and consolidated net income to make decisions aligned with Autodesk’s strategic initiatives and go-to market strategies . The amounts of new transaction model and stock-based compensation are excluded from this line and presented separately within this table .
 Autodesk’s revenue is divided into subscription revenue, maintenance revenue, and other revenue . Long-lived assets exclude deferred tax assets, marketable securities, goodwill, and intangible assets . The company's revenue is recognized when control for these offerings is transferred to our customers, in an amount that reflects the consideration we expect to be entitled to in exchange for products and services .
 Judgment is required to determine the level of integration and interdependency between individual components of desktop software applications and cloud functionalities . This determination influences whether desktop software is considered distinct and accounted for separately as a license performance obligation recognized at the time of delivery . For product subscriptions and flexible EBA subscriptions, the single performance obligation is recognized ratably over the contract term as the subscription is delivered .
 Autodesk established the relative standalone selling price (SSP) of each obligation . Judgment is required to determine whether our distributors and resellers have the ability to honor their commitment to pay, regardless of whether they collect payment from their customers . The deferred costs are then amortized over the period of benefit .
 Commissions paid to our solution providers that are related to contract renewals may either be commensurate or non-commensurate with commissions earned on the initial contract . Costs for initial contracts that are non-commissioned on renewal contracts are amortized on a straight-line basis over the period of benefit . Amortization expense is included in marketing and sales expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Operations .
 Key inputs for currency derivatives are spot rates, forward rates, interest rates, volatility, and credit default rates . Autodesk reviews for potential changes on a quarterly basis, in conjunction with our fiscal quarter-end close . The Company has elected to use the income approach to value derivatives using the observable Level 2 .
 Autodesk classifies its marketable securities as either short-term or long-term generally based on each instrument’s underlying contractual maturity date . The company's strategic investments consist of privately held debt and equity securities. The cost of securities sold is based on the specific-identification method. The company carries all “trading securities” at fair value, with unrealized gains and losses, net of tax .
 Autodesk's strategic investments in debt and equity securities (Level 3) are valued using significant unobservable inputs or data in an inactive market . The valuation requires the Company’s judgment due to the absence of market prices and inherent lack of liquidity . The fair value would then be adjusted positively or negatively based on available information such as pricing in recent rounds of financing .
 The credit loss is measured as the amount by which the debt security’s amortized cost basis exceeds the estimate of the present value of cash flows expected to be collected . Credit-related impairment is recognized as an allowance on the Consolidated Balance Sheets with a corresponding adjustment to “Interest and other expense, net”
 Autodesk uses derivative instruments to manage its short-term exposures to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates that exist as part of ongoing business operations . For additional information, see “Concentration of Credit Risk” within this Note 1, “Business and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies” and “Financial Instruments”
 Autodesk accounts for these derivative instruments as either assets or liabilities on the balance sheet and carries them at fair value . Gains and losses resulting from changes in fair value are accounted for depending on the use of the derivative and whether it is designated and qualifies for hedge accounting . The bank counterparties to the derivative contracts potentially expose Autodek to credit-related losses in the event of their nonperformance .
 Autodesk uses foreign currency contracts to reduce the exchange rate impact on a portion of the net revenue or operating expense of certain anticipated transactions . The effectiveness of the cash flow hedge contracts is assessed quantitatively using regression at inception and thereafter . The gains and losses on these hedges are included in “Accumulated other comprehensive income (loss)”
 Autodesk uses foreign currency contracts that are not designated as hedging instruments to reduce exchange rate risk associated with foreign currency denominated receivables, payables, and cash . These forward contracts are marked-to-market at the end of each fiscal quarter with gains and losses recognized as “Interest and other income (expense), net”
 Autodesk has a partner incentive program that uses quarterly attainment of monetary rewards to motivate distributors and resellers to achieve mutually agreed upon business goals in a specified time period . The majority of these incentives are recorded as a reduction to accounts receivable and deferred revenue in the period the transaction is billed . Allowances for credit losses on trade receivables and contract assets were not material as of January 31, 2025 .
 Autodesk’s accounts receivable are derived from sales to a large number of resellers, distributors, and direct customers in the Americas, Europe, Middle East and Africa (“EMEA”), and Asia Pacific (APAC) geographies . Citibank, N.A., an affiliate of Citigroup, is one of the lead lenders and an agent in the syndicate of a $1.5-billion revolving credit facility .
 Autodesk’s intangible assets include customer relationships, developed technologies, trade names and patents, and other, and the related accumulated amortization . These assets are presented as “Intangible assets, net” in the Consolidated Balance Sheets . Amortization expense for intangible assets was $134.2 billion in fiscal 2025, $89 million in fiscal 2024, and $298 million in fiscal 2023 .
 Computer equipment, software, furniture, leasehold improvements, land and buildings depreciated using straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the assets . Depreciation expense for intangible assets for each of the fiscal years ended thereafter is as follows:  depreciation expense was $.43.00 million in fiscal 2025, $47 million in  2024, and $.50 million in fiscal 2023 . Impairment losses were   in fiscal years  ended January 31, 2025, 2024 and 2023.
 Autodesk enters into certain cloud-based software hosting arrangements that are accounted for as service contracts . Costs incurred for these arrangements are capitalized for application development activities, if material, and immediately expensed for preliminary project activities and post-implementation activities . Software development costs incurred subsequent to the establishment of technological feasibility through the period of general market availability of the products are generally amortized over a two-year period .
 Operating lease right-of-use assets and operating lease liabilities are recognized at commencement date based on the present value of lease payments over the lease term . Autodesk records the tangible and intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination based on their estimated fair values at the date of the respective acquisition, with the exception of contract assets and contract liabilities (i.e., deferred revenue)
 The fair values assigned to the identifiable intangible assets acquired are based on estimates and assumptions determined by management . Autodesk records the excess of consideration transferred over the aggregate fair values as goodwill . The impairment to be recognized is equal to the amount by which the carrying value of the assets exceeds its fair market value . See Note 9, “Leases” for further discussion on impairment charges of lease related right-of-assets .
 Autodesk tests goodwill for impairment annually in its fourth fiscal quarter or more often . Goodwill impairment exists when the estimated fair value of goodwill is less than its carrying value . If impairment exists, the carrying value of the goodwill is reduced to fair value through an impairment charge recorded in the Company’s consolidated statements of operations .
 The following table summarizes the changes in the carrying amount of goodwill during the fiscal years ended January 31, 2025 and 2024 . The value of the goodwill is based on the Company's valuation of assets and liabilities assumed . Autodesk performs a quarterly assessment of the recoverability of these net deferred tax assets and believes it will generate sufficient future taxable income in appropriate tax jurisdictions to realize the net deferred tax assets .
 Autodesk determines the grant date fair value of its stock-based payment awards for grants of employee stock purchases related to the employee stock purchase plan using the Black-Scholes-Merton (“BSM”) option-pricing model . The Monte Carlo simulation model utilizes multiple input variables to estimate the probability that market conditions will be achieved. is more likely than not to be realized.
 Autodesk uses the following assumptions to estimate the fair value of stock-based awards . The variables used in these models are reviewed when awards are granted and adjusted as needed . Stock-based compensation cost for restricted stock is measured on the closing fair market value of our common stock on the date of grant . The expected volatility for performance stock units subject to market conditions includes the expected volatility of companies within the S&P North American Technology Software Index with a market capitalization over $2.0 billion .
 The risk-free interest rate used in the BSM option pricing model and the Monte Carlo simulation model is the historical yield on U.S. Treasury securities with equivalent remaining lives . The funded status of Autodesk’s defined benefit pension plans is measured as the difference between the fair value of plan assets and the projected benefit obligation for the fiscal years presented .
 There have been no recent changes in accounting pronouncements issued by FASB or adopted by the Company during the fiscal year ended January 31, 2025, that are applicable to the Company . The measurement of projected benefit obligations and net periodic benefit obligations is based on estimates and assumptions that reflect the terms of the plans .
 FASB issued ASU No. 2023-07, “Segment Reporting (Topic 280: Improvements to Reportable Segment Disclosures’s’ Disclosure requirements . Autodesk adopted the annual disclosures of ASU 20 23-07 for our fiscal year ended January 31, 2025 . ASU 2024-03 requires disaggregated disclosures of certain categories of expenses .
 In December 2023, the FASB issued ASU No. 2023-09, “Income Taxes (Topic 740): Improvement to Income Tax Disclosures’s transparency and usefulness of income tax disclosures . Autodesk is currently evaluating the effect of adopting ASU 2024-03 on its disclosures .
 Autodesk does not have any material variable consideration, such as obligations for returns, refunds, warranties, or amounts due to customers for which significant estimation or judgment is required as of the reporting date . As of January 31, 2025, Autodek had remaining performance obligations of $6.94 billion, which represents the total transaction price allocated to remaining performance obligation .
 The following tables summarize the Company’s financial instruments by significant investment category as of January 31, 2025 and 2024 . Contract assets relate to performance completed in advance of scheduled billings . The satisfaction of performance obligations typically lags behind billings under revenue contracts from customers . The amount of remaining performance obligations may be impacted by the specific timing, duration, and size of customer subscription and support agreements .
 The investments are classified as debt securities . They include corporate debt securities, government securities, mortgage-backed securities, and US treasury bonds . These investments are included in “Cash and cash equivalents” or “Long-term other assets” in the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets . See Note 7, "Deferred Compensation" for more information .
 Autodesk monitors all marketable debt securities for potential credit losses by reviewing indicators such as, but not limited to, current credit indicators . The following table summarizes the fair values of investments classified as marketable . debt securities by contractual maturity date as of January 31, 2025: Fair Value (1) due within 1 year, (2) due in 1 year through 5 years, (5) through 10 years; (6) due after 10 years: (7) Average fair value (fair value)
 There were  no allowances for credit losses as of January 31, 2025 and 2024 . Realized gains and losses from the sale or redemption of marketable securities are recorded in “rewarded interest and other income (expense), net’s) on the Company's Consolidated Statements of Operations . Autodesk uses the measurement alternative to account for adjustment to these investments in a given quarter .
 Autodesk applies fair value accounting for certain financial assets and liabilities, which consist of cash equivalents, marketable securities, and other financial instruments . The Company defines fair value as the price that would be received from selling an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date .Autodesk does not consider the remaining investments to be impaired as of January 31, 2025 .
 These investments are classified as debt securities . They are included in “Cash and cash equivalents” in the accompanying Consolidated Balance Sheets . They include money market funds, U.S. government securities, commercial paper, mortgage-backed securities, and US treasury bonds . See Note 7, "Deferred Compensation" for more information .
 The 2022 Equity Incentive Plan (the 2022 Plan) was approved by Autodesk’s stockholders and became effective on June 16, 2022 . The 2022 Plan permits the grant of stock options, restricted stock units, and restricted stock awards to employees and non-employee members of the Board of Directors .
 The 2022 Plan will expire on March 17, 2032 . At January 31, 2025, approximately  approximately  around 8.8 million shares were available for future issuance under the 2022 Plan . The fair value of the shares vested during fiscal years ended January  31, 25, 2024, and 2023 were $245.32, $200.53.53, and $198.89.89, respectively .
 Restricted stock units are not considered outstanding stock at the time of grant . The fair value of the restricted stock units is expensed ratably over the vesting period . At January 31, 2025, Autodesk granted 279,279,000 performance stock units for which the ultimate number of shares earned is determined based on the achievement of performance criteria .
 The fair value of the performance stock units is expensed using the accelerated attribution method over the  “Relative TSR’s” vesting period . Autodesk recorded stock-based compensation expense related to performance stock . units of $57.0 to $42.0 billion .
 At January 31, 2025, the number of performance stock units granted but unvested was 541 . thousand . The ESPP, which was approved by stockholders in 1998, does not have an expiration date . The Company issues shares on the first trading day following March 31 and September 30 of each fiscal year .
 Autodesk’s ESPP. s granted to employees and directors, as well as the number of securities remaining available for future issuance under these plans as of January 31, 2025 . The provision for income taxes consists of the following: The U.S. statutory rate and the aggregate income tax provision are as follows .
 Autodesk’s fiscal 2025 tax expense is primarily driven by the U.S. and foreign tax expense, including withholding taxes on payments made to the United States or to Singapore from foreign sources, a partial audit settlement with the IRS, and related increase in reserves, offset by a decrease in tax expense relating to stock-based compensation and the tax benefit from the valuation allowance release in Australia .
 Autodesk continues to retain a valuation allowance against Portugal, New Zealand, California, Massachusetts and Michigan deferred tax assets . The valuation allowance increased by $1,173.2 million in fiscal 2024, due to the establishment of valuation allowance in Massachusetts offset with the release of the valuation allowance . The Company has elected to recognize a . recognition of a . valuation allowance through goodwill in Australia related to negative evidence at the time of the Payapps Limited acquisition; however, due . to positive evidence supporting the realization of its deferred tax . assets .
 Autodesk has $7.7.2 million of cumulative U.S. federal tax loss carryforwards and $316 million of . cumulative . state tax losses . Portugal, Norway, New Zealand and other foreign jurisdictions incurred tax losses totaling $20. ny potential GILTI obligations as an expense in the period it is incurred .
 California and Massachusetts cumulative assets have full valuation allowance against them on our balance sheet as the Company has determined it is more likely than not that these losses and credits will not be utilized . No ownership change has occurred through the balance sheet date that would result in permanent losses of the U.S. federal and state tax attributes .
 The Internal Revenue Service notified the Company of examination of the Company’s consolidated federal income tax returns for fiscal 2020 and 2021 . Autodesk settled on a partial disallowance of research and development credits and consequently the reserve on such credits for years not under audit has increased . There was $9.9.6 million, $2.2 million, and $7.7 million, net of tax benefit, accrued for interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as of January 31, 2025, 2024, and 2023 .
 Pro forma results of operations have not been presented because the effects of these acquisitions were not material to Autodesk’s Consolidated Financial Statements . Results of operations for the following acquisitions are included in the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Operations since their respective acquisition dates . The acquisition is expected to foster broader collaboration and communication, as well as drive greater efficiencies, in the production process .
 Autodesk recorded the tangible and intangible assets acquired and liabilities assumed based on their estimated fair values at the date of each respective acquisition . The transaction costs related to the acquisitions were not material . The acquisition was primarily attributable to synergies expected to arise after the respective acquisition. Goodwill is expected to be deductible for U.S. income tax purposes for Payapps and PIX .
 Autodesk completed  two business combinations that were completed during the fiscal year ended January 31, 2025 . The allocation of purchase price consideration to certain assets and liabilities as well as the final amount of purchase consideration are not yet finalized . The acquisition-date fair value of the consideration transferred totaled $114 million .
 At January 31, 2025, Autodesk had investments in debt and equity securities that are held in a rabbi trust under non-qualified deferred compensation plans and a corresponding deferred compensation liability . Of the total consideration transferred, $.97% was considered purchase consideration . The remaining amount was recorded in “Prepaid expenses and other current assets’ and “Long-term other assets” on our Consolidated Balance Sheets .
 Current and non-current portions of the deferred compensation liability are recorded in the Consolidated Balance Sheets under “Accrued compensation” and “Long-term other liabilities” Autodesk did not recognize any contract cost impairment losses during the fiscal years ended January 31, 2025, 2024, or 2023 .
 The Credit Agreement contains customary covenants that could restrict the imposition of liens on Autodesk’s assets . At January 31, 2025, Autodek was in compliance with the Credit Agreement covenants . The interest rates for the revolving credit facility are subject to upward or downward adjustments, on an annual basis, if the Company achieves, or fails, certain sustainability-linked targets .
 Autodesk issued $2.4.4% notes due December 15, 2031 (“2021 Notes”) The maturity date on the Credit Agreement is September 30, 2026 . The 2021 Notes were designated as sustainability bonds, the net proceeds of which are used to fund environmentally and socially responsible projects in the following areas: eco-efficient products, production technologies, and processes .
 In June 2015, Autodesk issued $.300.00 million aggregate principal amount of  grotesque4.375.375% notes due June 15, 2025 (“ 2015 Notes”) The 2021 Notes, 2020 Notes, 2017 Notes, and the 2015 Notes may all be redeemed at any time, subject to a make whole premium .
 Autodesk has operating leases for real estate, vehicles and certain equipment . Leases do not contain residual value guarantees or material restrictive covenants . Short-term leases are recognized in the Consolidated Statement of Operations on a straight-line basis over the lease term . Payments under our lease arrangements are primarily fixed, however, certain lease agreements contain variable payments, which are expensed as incurred and not included in the operating lease assets and liabilities .
 Autodesk recorded operating lease right-of-use assets impairment charges during the fiscal year ended January 31, 2025 . The operating lease-related asset impairments are included in “general and administrative” in the Company’s Consolidated Statements of Operations . The impairment charges included $9.9.2 million and $29.29 million, respectively .
 The weighted average remaining lease term for operating leases is   around 5.8 years and  6.2 years at January 31, 2025 and 2024, respectively . Cash paid for operating lease payments included in operating cash flows (1) Includes $13.7 million, $16.16 million, and $.14 million in variable lease payments not included in “Operating lease liabilities” and “Long-term operating lease liabilities .”
 Autodesk has subleased certain office space to a third party and has classified the sublease as an operating lease . Sublease income is recorded as a reduction of lease expense in the Company’s Consolidated Statements of Operations . The sublease has a remaining lease term of  7.1-year .
 Autodesk uses foreign currency contracts to reduce the exchange rate impact on a portion of the net revenue or operating expense of certain anticipated transactions . Currency collars and forward contracts are designated and documented as cash flow hedges . Outstanding contracts are recognized as either assets or liabilities on the Company’s Consolidated Balance Sheets at fair value .
 Autodesk has certain royalty commitments associated with the sale and licensing of certain products . Purchasing commitments as of January 31, 2025, were approximately $395.9 million for periods through fiscal 2033 . Indemnifications include limited product warranties and indemnification of customers against claims of intellectual property infringement made by third parties arising from the use of its products or services .
 Autodesk has agreements whereby it indemnifies its officers and directors for certain events or occurrences while the officer or director is, or was, serving in such capacity . The maximum potential amount of future payments Autodeksk could be required to make under these indemnification agreements is unlimited . Autodek has directors’ and officers’ liability insurance coverage that is intended to reduce its financial exposure .
 Autodesk says pending matters are not expected to have a material adverse impact on its consolidated results of operations, cash flows, or its financial position . The Audit Committee of the Board of Directors commenced an internal investigation with the assistance of outside counsel and advisors regarding the Company’s free cash flow and non-GAAP operating margin practices . On April 24, 2024, Michael Barkasi filed a purported federal securities class action complaint in the Northern District of California .
 Autodesk has stock repurchase programs that are used to offset dilution from the issuance of stock under the Company’s employee stock plans . At this stage, the Company cannot reasonably estimate the amount of any possible financial loss that could result from this matter . The action purports to be brought on behalf of those who purchased or otherwise acquired the Company's securities between February 23, 2023 and April 16, 2024 .
 Share repurchase programs do not have an expiration date and the pace and timing of repurchases will depend on factors such as cash generation from operations, available surplus, the volume of employee stock plan activity, remaining shares available in the authorized pool, cash requirements for acquisitions and cash requirements to retire outstanding debt, economic and market conditions, stock price, and legal and regulatory requirements .
 Net Income Per Share is computed using the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period . Diluted net income per share does not include shares that are an option . Reclassifications related to gains and losses on available-for-sale debt securities are included in “Interest and other income (expense), net”
 Autodesk has a 401(k) plan that covers nearly all U.S. employees . Eligible employees may contribute up to  grotesquely-75% of their pretax salary . The Company provides certain defined benefit pension plans to employees located in countries outside of the United States, primarily the United Kingdom, Switzerland, and Japan .
 Autodesk recognized an aggregate pension liability for the funded status of $9.9.2 million and $6.6 million in “Long-term other liabilities” on the Consolidated Balance Sheet as of January 31, 2025, and . 31, 2024, respectively . Our total net periodic pension plan cost was $3.3 billion for fiscal years 2025, 2024 and 2023 . Our expected funding for the plans during fiscal 2026 is approximately $2 billion .
 During fiscal 2026, Autodesk initiated a restructuring plan (“2026 Plan”) to support its initiatives to optimize its go-to-market organization and, at the same time, to reallocate resources to investments in cloud, platform and artificial intelligence . The 2026 Plan includes a gross reduction in force that will result in the aggregate termination of approximately  around 9% of the Company’s workforce .
 Autodesk, Inc. presented fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of the Company at January 31, 2025 and 2024, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles . We are a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB and are required to be independent with respect to the Company .
 Critical audit matter relates to accounts or disclosures that are material to the financial statements . The communication of the critical audit matter does not alter in any way our opinion on the consolidated financial statements, taken as a whole, and we are not providing a separate opinion . We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion .
 Auditing Autodesk's revenue recognition was challenging and complex due to the effort required to analyze the accounting treatment for the Company’s various product and service offerings in accordance with ASC 606, Revenue from Contracts with Customers . This involved assessing the impact of terms and conditions in contracts with customers to determine whether products and services are considered distinct performance obligations and the related timing of revenue recognition .
 Autodesk, Inc. (the Company) maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of January 31, 2025, based on criteria established in Internal Control—Integrated Framework issued by Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (2013 framework) (the COSO criteria) We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States)
 Internal Control Over Financial Reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting . Internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company . We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion .
 Internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements . We maintain “disclosure controls and procedures,” as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) and 15d-15 under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the “Exchange Act”) Our disclosure controls are designed to ensure that information required to be disclosed in our Exchange Act reports is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported .
 Autodesk's management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting . Management does not expect that our disclosure controls and procedures will necessarily prevent all errors and all fraud . A control system, no matter how well conceived and operated, can provide only reasonable, not absolute, assurance that the objectives of the control system are met .
 There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the three months ended January 31, 2025 . The following director(s) and officer(s), as defined in Rule 16a-1(f), adopted a “Rule 10b5-1 trading arrangement’s’ duration of the trading arrangement is until  December 4, 2026 .
 The following sets forth certain information as of March 6, 2025, regarding our executive officers . The information required by this Item is incorporated herein by reference to the sections entitled “Proposal One: Election of Directors,” “Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners and Management”  “Governance and our Board of Directors” in our Proxy Statement .
 Dr. Anagnost held various engineering, sales, marketing and product management positions at Lockheed Aeronautical Systems Company and EXA Corporation . Janesh Moorjani previously served as Chief Financial Officer of Elastic NV (“Elastic”), a software company for search-powered solutions, since August 2017 . Steven M. Blum served as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer since November 1, 2022 .
 Ruth Ann Keene has served as Executive Vice President, Corporate Affairs, Chief Legal Officer & Corporate Secretary since May 2022 . Rebecca Pearce previously served as HR Director Global Territory Sales from February 2018 to September 2018 . Before joining Autodesk, Ms. Keene was a technology transactions attorney at Morrison & Foerster, LLP. Rebecca Pearce was the HR Director for Dyson Limited from December 2011 to September 2015 .
 The following documents are filed as part of this Report: The information concerning Autodesk’s financial statements and the Report of  Ernst & Young LLP, Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm (PCAOB ID:  grotesque42) The information required by this Item is incorporated herein by reference to the sections entitled “Governance and our Board of Directors” and “Executive Compensation—Equity Compensation Plan Information” in our Proxy Statement .

The exhibits listed on the accompanying Index to Exhibits immediately prior to the signature page of this Form 10-K.
